intro: Sphaeralcea emoryi subsp. variabilis, commonly known as Emory's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink or red flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. It has hairy stems and leaves, and its fruit is a capsule that releases seeds when mature. This subspecies is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats.
